bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, April 9, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg sends Hench a proof of a Cornwell painting of McDowell, and tells him of a forthcoming Wyeth booklet that will present and describe all four Cornwell paintings, including "The Conquerors of Yellow Fever."

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, April 9, 1942
div1.opener:
TELEPHONE
MURRAY HILL 6-3570
CABLE ADDRESS
MURRADAG
JOHN F. MURRAY ADVERTISING AGENCY
INCORPORATED
NEW YORK
FORTY-ONE EAST FORTY-SECOND STREET
April 9, 1942
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
You did not hear from me when I was in Chicago as I spent
only a day and a half in the city and had to rush to catch
my train back to New York. I am afraid that the matter of
calcium solution will have to wait for some time. Even
though I might get very enthusiastic about it myself I am
afraid I will not have much luck in interesting the techni-
cal departments of any of our companies as they merely smile
when I mention the subject. It does not have the pharmaceut-
ical appeal necessary to intrigue their interest and I am
afraid that their attitude is the proper one.

Attached find a proof from the small color plates on the
MdDowell painting. I have not yet arrived at a good title
for the picture as I want one which is short and euphonious.

I think you will be interested in knowing that we are getting
out a small 12-page booklet with 4-color reproductions of all
four paintings so far completed in the series. The color
plates will be about half the size of the one enclosed in this
letter. The booklet will contain the story of each picture
insofar as we can crowd it into one small page for each paint-
ing. The back outside cover will carry a short history of
John Wyeth and Brother. The first printing will be 150,000,
a fair percentage of which will be distributed at medical con-
ferences or wherever the pictures are shown during the coming
year. I will submit the copy for the Yellow Fever painting
before we go to press, as the question is where will we want
to lay the emphasis in a situation where the space is so
limited.

We are considering offering the booklet to science teachers in
high schools and knowing the situation pretty well I can see
the demand in terms of millions providing we can get the money
to supply them.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
GAK:L
Enclosure (1)
P.S. The above address is my permanent business address from
now on.
G. A. K.
